column1: Cervical dysplasia refers to abnormal changes in the cells on the surface of the cervix.
Most often, cervical dysplasia is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
HPV is a common virus that is spread through sexual contact.
Other types of HPV can cause genital warts.

The following may increase your risk of cervical dysplasia: - Having sex before age 18 - Having a baby before age 16 - Having multiple sexual partners - Having other illnesses, such as diabetes or HIV - Using medicines that suppress your immune system - Smoking
A colposcopy is a procedure performed in your health care provider's office.

It is grouped into three categories: - CIN I -- mild dysplasia - CIN II -- moderate to marked dysplasia - CIN III -- severe dysplasia to carcinoma in situ Some strains of HPV are known to cause cervical cancer.
An HPV DNA test can identify the high-risk types of HPV linked to this cancer.
This test may be done: - As a screening test for women over age 30 - For women of any age who have a slightly abnormal Pap test result
Mild dysplasia (LSIL or CIN I) may go away without treatment.

Treatment for moderate-to-severe dysplasia or mild dysplasia that does not go away may include: - Cryosurgery to freeze abnormal cells - Laser therapy, which uses light to burn away abnormal tissue - LEEP (loop electrosurgical excision procedure), which uses electricity to remove abnormal tissue - Surgery to remove the abnormal tissue (cone biopsy) - Hysterectomy (in rare cases) If you have had dysplasia, you will need to have repeat exams every 12 months or as recommended by your provider.
This vaccine prevents many cervical cancers.
Girls who receive this vaccine before they become sexually active reduce their chance of getting cervical cancer.
Smoking increases your risk of developing more severe dysplasia and cancer.
